Policy: Crisis Supplement

 

In determining eligibility for a crisis supplement the client must meet all of the criteria in the following four bullets:

 
  • Is the family unit eligible for income assistance, disability assistance, or hardship assistance?
    • Ie: No eligibility for crisis supplement exists unless the family unit is eligible for support and/or shelter in the calendar month. 
  • Does the family unit require the supplement to meet an unexpected expense or obtain an item unexpectedly needed?
  • Is the family unit unable to meet the expense or obtain the item because there are no other resources available to the family unit?
  • Will failure to meet the expense or obtain the item result in imminent danger to physical health of a person in the family unit or removal of a child under the Child, Family and Community Service Act? (This criterion must apply in conjunction with all bullets.  It is not an independent criterion)

A crisis supplement is intended to aid the client in an emergency when all other resources have been exhausted. A crisis supplement must not be provided to support an ongoing situation or as a way to provide assistance that is prohibited by other regulatory direction. [See Policy – Limitations]

Inconsistent practice identified – Not limited to, but inconsistent practice of issuing a crisis supplement mostly originates from staff’s interpretation of “unexpected”.

 
Solution for consistency: Example based definition of the word “unexpected”. Unexpected would be “unforeseen and beyond the control of the client”. Examples below are not exhaustive and should be used as guidance in conjunction with sound judgment and case consultation.
 
 
Not unexpected ​
  • Food, clothing and furniture – Lost or abandoned by the client due to their own actions.
  • Clothing - request due to gradual weight loss as opposed to rapid or sudden weight loss.
  • Clothing - request due to the seasons.
  • Shelter or Utility - request when the client has elected not to pay these bills.
​
Unexpected ​
  • ​Costs arising from an event beyond the clients control.
  • Costs associated with the treatment of bedbugs or other infestations.
       
   
* The client’s cognitive abilities should be considered when evaluating what is within the clients control.
 

 

Strategy to assist Clients in need:
 
  • When a client found eligible for a crisis supplement picks up the Purchase authorization or cheque ensure that the client is advised of community resources that would assist them for future emergencies.  Provide the client with your local community resource sheet.
  • Advise clients of resources available to them, including tax credits.
  • Mid month cheque held back for emergencies where pattern of crisis supplement reliance is observed. Consider mailing cheques out when appropriate to prevent line ups.
  • Ensure clients are getting all the assistance and supplements for which they are entitled.
  • Ensure they have an active employment plan and/or, review for compliance.
 
Considerations during your eligibility assessment:
 
  • Is the expense or item required as a direct result of an ongoing situation?
  • Has the client previously been issued a supplement to meet this need in this month or a recent month?
  • Is the item or expense required as a result of actions or inactions over which the client had direct control?
  • Could the client reasonably have been expected to foresee that his expense would occur or that this item would be needed?  The client’s cognitive abilities should also be considered at this stage.
  
Recording Decisions:
 
  • Record how the eligibility decision has been reached i.e.: how each of the 4 eligibility criteria have been met or not met:
  1. Eligible for assistance
  2. Unexpected and beyond the control of the client
  3. No other resources were available
  4. Failure would cause imminent danger to the physical health or the removal of a child
  • Advise the client of the full reasons for the denial, offer a written decision or right to reconsideration. Record the details on ICM.  The written decision or reconsideration should include: (1) the request (2) the circumstance that gave rise to it (3) the denial and the reason for it citing what criterion/criteria were not met.
  • Record details regarding any alternate community resources offered to assist the client.   

 

Payment of Crisis Supplement:
 
  • Crisis supplements for shelter should be made direct to the landlord.
  • An imprest cheque in the client’s name is the preferred method of payment of a crisis supplement.  However, if a supplier cheque is warranted in some instances, staff may do so.
  • The office community resource sheet is to be given out when the client is picking up a crisis supplement or mailed out with the supplement cheque that goes directly to the client.


Crisis Supplement Key Messages

In introducing this to staff the following points should be highlighted:

  • Eligibility for a crisis supplement is based upon meeting the criteria set out in regulation.
    • Family unit must be eligible for income assistance, disability assistance or hardship assistance
    • The supplement is required to meet an UNEXPECTED need, and
    • there are no other resources available to meet the need, and
    • failure to meet the need will result in imminent danger to the person’s physical health or removal of a child under CFCSA.
  • In your team meetings, please discuss the definition of unexpected as it is stated in the practice advisory.
  • Educate clients about community resources and tax credits that may be available to them.
  • Always review the file to ensure that the client is receiving everything for which he or she is eligible and to discuss job search and employment programs.
  • Always message that the clothing supplement is not a yearly allowance or entitlement, and do not routinely issue $100.00 – but rather, issue based upon need.
  • Please make the crisis supplement cheque in the client’s name.  However, staff maintain the discretion to make the cheque payable to a supplier, as there will/may be cases where this is warranted (e.g. crisis supplement to a landlord, hydro,.. etc)  
  • If a supplier does not accept supplier cheques, please find out if the supplier would be willing to have a copy of the original cheque faxed to confirm the legitimacy of the cheque.

Policy:
Purpose:

To clarify what to issue to a client who is in an acute care bed in an acute care facility such as a hospital.

Background:

There have been regional inconsistencies about what to issue when a client is admitted to an acute care facility.  Some regions issue support while other regions issue comforts allowance.  Legislation does not stipulate what is to be issued when an applicant or client is in an acute care facility unless they have been admitted to a hospital because they require extended care.   Under Living Arrangements – Temporarily Reduced Family Unit it states that support and shelter allowances must normally be decreased. 

Practice:

When a client is admitted to an acute care facility such as a hospital it is necessary to determine if the client is in an acute care bed or an extended care bed.  Hospitals sometimes designate acute care beds as extended care beds while waiting for an extended care bed in the community.  Legislation states that we pay comforts if a client is in an extended care bed.  If the client is in an acute care bed, their support allowance will not be decreased but will continue at the rate appropriate to the family unit.

Legislation:

Is silent on what to issue when a client has been admitted to an acute care facility for a short term stay.

Purpose:
 
To establish a consistent lower mainland practice for closing and re-opening recently closed files.
 
 
Practice:
 
Case Management
 
  1. Files where computer cheques are not picked up because the client did not submit a stub are to be closed by the 5th of the following month.  DO NOT RELY ON THE 2 MONTH AUTO-CLOSURE.
  2. Where a cheque was not picked up because the client did not respond to the cheque signal letter (SD3238), the cheque is to be cancelled, cheque production turned off, and the File Closure Letter (SD3133) sent.  The file is to be BF’d for closure in 20 business days from the date the client is expected to have received the letter.  Document in CTS.
  3. In the case of a client identified as Homeless follow procedures below:

Close files if client circumstances are known e.g. moved to another province, client has deceased.  If client has a BC Housing Outreach Worker, consult with Outreach Worker prior to closing file.

If client has not returned to the office for assistance and their circumstances are unknown, allow files to auto-close after six months of no contact from the client.
 
      4.  When indicated on the SD 81 that Income Assistance is no longer needed, close the file at the end of the month for which assistance was last paid.
 

       5.   A Person with Disabilities file should not be closed until the client has been contacted regarding possible continued eligibility for medical coverage.  Contact may be made by phone or by using the attached letter (see Attachment #1). The letter should include a “response by” date and the file should be BF’d for closure after that date. 

 
At Application
Abandoned - if a client does not return to complete the pre-application process, allow the system to automatically close the PA file.
Abandoned - if a GA file has been opened and client does not return to complete the eligibility interview, allow the system to automatically close the GA file.  (e.g. GA was opened and client was asked to submit further documentation to determine eligibility but never returned.)
 
Re-Opening Closed Files
 
If a client approaches the office for assistance within 2 weeks after file closure the EAW may exercise discretion in re-opening the file;  for example, if the client indicates they have been hospitalized or there has been an emergency in the family.  Files should not be routinely re-opened.
 
Housekeeping
  1. If the office is aware that a couple is separating, or if the file is open in name of a client who has passed away, the office will make arrangements to open a file for the partner if income assistance is still required.
  2. All relevant close codes must be used when closing a file eg., Time limits, Family Maintenance, Earnings, etc.

PURPOSE:

To clarify how the ministry treats income during the month of application and how to treat ongoing income at application.
 

PRACTICE:

If an applicant has received income prior to application the ministry will not consider the income in the calculation of assistance because the applicant received the money prior to coming under the purview of the Employment and Assistance or Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities legislation.  In the case of applicants applying under the Employment and Assistance legislation if there are any funds in excess of $150.00 or $250.00 (depending on family composition) available from the income it would be treated as cash assets at application.
 
For those applicants who have ongoing monthly income such as a pension, family maintenance or E.I., the ministry will not deduct the income at application if the income is less than the assistance rate for the family unit.  If the ongoing monthly income is in excess of the assistance rate for the family unit then the applicant is not eligible for assistance unless they are in a hardship situation and meet the Hardship G (excess income) criteria.
 
The monthly ongoing income is to be entered onto the AP3 screen so that it will be deducted from the following month’s assistance.  If you have to issue two imprest cheques, one for the month of application and one for the following month you will need to deduct the ongoing income from the imprest cheque.
 
For those applicants whose income is ongoing but not a predictable amount, do not enter the income on the AP3 screen.  The client needs to get into the regular reporting cycle so advise the client to report their income for the month of application on the stub that is attached to their next computer generated cheque.  For example, if an applicant applies on June 10 they are to be advised to enter all income received from June 10-30 on the cheque stub that they will receive on their July cheque which must be returned to the office by July 5.  That reported income will affect their August assistance.
 
For those applicants who apply after cut-off, the situation must be dealt with differently because the applicant will receive two imprest cheques and an automatic computer generated cheque for the third month of assistance.  For example, an application is completed June 27.  The applicant is issued pro-rated support and shelter if required and full July assistance by imprest cheque.  The computer will automatically generate a cheque for August without a stub being submitted, however and especially if the client has ongoing earnings the EAW is going to insist that the client completes a stub for August assistance.  You may need to signal the August cheque to ensure that earnings are declared.  The client will declare income received from June 27 to June 30 and hopefully this will capture one pay cheque which will be deducted from August assistance.  For September the recipient will have full July income to declare and they will now be on the proper reporting cycle.

Topic: LTC Entitlement (support vs comfort allowance)​ and Involuntary Separation (spouse entering treatment)
Policy:
Best Practice: LTC and involuntary separation:
 
When an applicant or recipient of income assistance has separated involuntarily from a spouse (partner) because they are entering a care facility (unlikely to return home in the near future), income and assets will be treated as if the person is a single person. The following bullets provide more detail:
 

  • Every applicant who is separating from a spouse signs the Family Maintenance Assignment of Rights Form (HSD2748). This authorises the ministry to pursue spousal support if there is substantial reason to believe the spouse can provide financial support. Family Maintenance Workers will assess.
  • The family home (primary residence) is treated as an exempt asset. There is no requirement for the applicant to remove their name from title.
  • The total value of all shared assets (meaning assets where both parties are owners of the asset) will be divided by two and the applicant or recipient’s share will be treated as an asset. This means if the total value is over the allowable asset level for a single person they will be ineligible.
  • If the applicant is sole owner of the asset it is not divided; likewise if the spouse is the sole owner the asset is not considered.
  • The client or applicant can/should use the available asset as a resource to support themselves until the total value of their available asset is within the allowable asset level for that client. At that time they can re-apply for assistance.

NOTE: It is never appropriate to advise a client to transfer “ownership” of assets to another party in order to make themselves eligible. This is considered an inadequate disposal of assets under section 14 of the Employment and Assistance Act and section 13 of the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Act. If an applicant declares they have been supporting themselves with money drawn from assets they must provide documents to verify and account for their spending of it. If staff are uncertain if the person’s living expenses, or accounting of how they spent their money, would be considered reasonable, staff should seek approval from their supervisor and/or PPIM.

Purpose:

To provide clear guidelines as to when and how time limit consequences and employment plan sanctions are imposed for post 24 month time limit clients exiting assistance.

Practice:


Passive Client – one who passively exits income assistance for failing to submit a stub, or who does not contact office for a signaled or directed cheque.

Do Not:

 

  • Apply Employment Plan sanctions.
  • Close file for Employment Plan non-compliance.
  • Apply time limit consequences.
  • Use the time limit close code.

Do:

 

  • Record comments of possible non-compliance.
  • Place INF alert on file with Supervisor approval.  Alert to state:
“TL implications to be reviewed in consultation with Supervisor if client re-applies.”
 

As the ministry does not know why the client exited assistance it is not appropriate to apply sanctions or consequences.

 
Active Non-Compliant Client – one for whom the ministry is denying further assistance because the ministry has evidence of non-compliance, has discussed non-compliance with the client, and has determined that the client is no longer eligible.

 

Time limit consequences apply when non-compliance occurs during or after month 25.
If the EAW is considering applying time limit consequences and employment plan or employment-related obligation sanctions the EAW must discuss with the Supervisor and complete the Time Limit Client Information Form.
Supervisor will review the case and if in agreement with imposing sanctions will forward the Time Limit Client Information form to the Manager of Policy and Program Implementation.
 
If consequences and sanctions are considered appropriate the EAW will do the following:
  • Advise client of non-compliance and consequences.
  • EAW advises client of right to reconsideration.
  • EAW advises client that they may be eligible for assistance if they meet one of the TL exclusion categories during the consequence period. 
  • All of the above must be recorded on the history.
  • EAW mails or gives appropriate template letter, either SD3075 or SD3076.
  • Employment Plan is closed with appropriate code.
  • Sanction is recorded on the IPP screen.
  • Time limits indicator (NC-X) code B recorded on PE1 screen.
  • BF file for closure at expiration of reconsideration period.
  • Use time limit close code and comment on CLS screen that time limit consequences are in effect.

Policy:
To clarify what process to use when encountering applicants and recipients who pay shelter costs equal to or in excess of their total monthly income assistance amount.

Practice:

Recipients currently in receipt of income assistance:
 
When recipients are in receipt of income assistance and are also paying shelter costs that are equal to or in excess of total monthly income assistance and family bonus, the Employment and Assistance Worker (EAW) must verify how the shelter is being paid. 


The recipient should be given the opportunity to explain how total shelter is being paid. The EAW should also confirm with the landlord if there is outstanding rent owing and, if yes, the amount.  If the landlord has temporarily reduced the rent, a letter or rental confirmation should be received to confirm the information.   If the recipient has given a plausible explanation as to how they are managing, the EAW must document the information and BF the file for further review at a later date.  If the recipient refuses to provide information or verify how rent is being paid, they may be ineligible for further assistance as per the Employment and Assistance Act and the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Act.

Note:  if the shelter equals but does not exceed the total monthly income assistance and family bonus, and the recipient has stated they eat at friends or relatives and go to the food bank or another food source for all their food, there are limited grounds to find the recipient ineligible for assistance.

Applicants for Income Assistance

When an applicant has shelter costs equal to or in excess of their total monthly income assistance rate, the EAW must review how the applicant’s monthly expenses (including car insurance, internet, etc.)  will be met considering their eligibility under Schedule A.  Any discussions must be carefully noted on the history.  The applicant should be referred to resources and encouraged to explore housing alternatives.   The case is to be reviewed in two months.  The applicant must understand any income, including in kind, or change in circumstance must be reported.  It is also important to ensure the applicant fully understands crisis supplements are for unexpected items of need and would likely not be available.   If the applicant refuses to provide information as to how shelter costs are being met, they may be declared ineligible for assistance. 

Note: Other cases that have relatively high shelter costs can be reviewed and, while a recipient can be found ineligible for refusing to provide or verify information, high shelter alone is not grounds for ineligibility.

Practice:

To ensure consistency throughout the Lower Mainland and to ensure addresses show correctly on the PCD L, the following conventions should be used.
 
  1. Street names should be entered as numbers not spelled out.

e.g.  0 Avenue – not Zero Avenue

       2.   No suffixes should be listed on street numbers.

e.g.  121 Street not 121st Street

       3.   There should be no spaces between “A” or “B” and the street number

e.g. 132A Street – not 132 A Street

       4.   Suite numbers should be in the “APT” line not the address line.

       5.   Suite numbers must be at least 2 characters e.g.  “01” not “1” so can be easily found on PCD.

       6.   Do not use hyphens in the address.

 e.g. 12465 101 Street not 12465 – 101 Street

       7.   Do not use punctuation in the address.

     8.   Do not use abbreviations

 e.g. Avenue not Ave or AV

Street not St

      9.     Do not enter anything other than the street address on the address line.

e.g. 18143 40 Avenue - not ABC House

ABC House           18143 40 Avenue

Note that entering addresses in the correct manner will enable the computer program used to change boundaries to enter all client addresses appropriately.  Incorrect address entry will also result in persons residing at the same addresses appearing to reside at different addresses on the PCD L

 
    10.  SIM and SUP cheques should always have the room/apartment/suite number and “For Deposit Only” in the line below the street to reduce potential fraud.
 
    11.  The name of the client and the name of the building (if any – such as SROs/BC Housing) must be entered in the “re:” section of SIM and SUP screens for any shelter payments including rent and security deposits  as suppliers of multiple addresses need to be able to match clients with addresses and suite #s.

Purpose:

To provide direction to staff regarding the process to follow when it is determined that a client has been underpaid due to administrative error.
 
Practice:

 

Legislation is silent on the topic of administrative error underpayments.  In the spirit of fairness, accountability, and providing client centred service the Ministry will backdate payments for up to 12 calendar months where an administrative error underpayment has been identified.

 
An administrative error underpayment is the result of SD staff either incorrectly actioning or not actioning a client request or submission resulting in the client receiving less than the prescribed or regulatory amount of assistance or supplements.   For example: 

 

  • Client submits a request for a diet allowance in March, the request is not actioned and the error is discovered at the eligibility review six months later.
  • Client submits rent receipt demonstrating that rent has risen from $275.00 to $325.00 but EAW has incorrectly entered rent amount at $300.00.
Requests to issue backdated monies to the client must be approved by the Manager, Policy and Program Implementation (PPIM) or the Director of Service Delivery (DSD).

 

All requests to issue backdated funds (including those where staff are unsure as to whether the underpayment is client or worked initiated) are to be routed to the PPIM via the attached regional form.

               
The PPIM will review the request, determine if it is an administrative underpayment and advise on method of correction.

Purpose:

Client files, including history comments are releasable to the client through the reconsideration process and under the Freedom of Information Act.  Ministry recordings must be complete, concise, informative and professional.

Practice:

 
History recordings must be factual only.

It is sometimes necessary to comment on negative interaction or an incident.  Comments do not need to be verbatim but simply a statement such as client was yelling, swearing, uttering profanities, throwing objects or slamming the door, etc.  In instances where a threat has been uttered it is appropriate to quote the comments verbatim.

 
The following should not constitute part of history recordings:

 

  • Judgmental statements including symbols such a exclamation marks
  • Personal opinions
  • Derogatory comments
  • Acronyms
  • Jargon other than ministry standard
  • Disagreements between workers

History records must always represent the ministry in a professional capacity.

Purpose:

To outline the procedures to be followed when completing a MSO review.

Practice:

 
Effective immediately staff will no longer be required to contact clients by telephone or letter to complete MSO reviews.

 

Annual MSO reviews can be completed yearly using the MIS/MOH screen.

Annual MSO reviews are conducted to confirm the client is residing in British Columbia. All Employment and Assistance Workers have access to the MIS/MOH screen. The MIS/MOH screen contains current information regarding the date of death for deceased clients and information regarding current MOH transactions.  By accessing information on the MIS/MOH screen, the need to contact clients directly when conducting MSO file reviews is eliminated.

Procedure:

 

  1. All MSO files must be reviewed yearly using the MIS/MOH screen to complete address and residency verification.
  2. MSO review information can be identified by accessing the MSO caseload or requesting MSO reports.
  3. Address verification is completed each time the MSO client contacts the EAO for service. 
  4. Each time the address is verified, the ACC screen is updated and the yearly review date is changed to reflect one year in the future.
  5. Prior to closing a Medical Services Only file, a complete review of the electronic file is completed to ensure eligibility is assessed for the surviving spouse to prevent possible service interruption.
  6. In circumstances where the MIS/MOH screen has been used to close a MSO file and the information has been determined to be incorrect, staff must use discretion to reopen the MSO file to prevent possible service interruption and/or medical billing to the client.

Purpose:

To clarify that Temporary Absence Assistance (code 46) may be issued not only when a child is removed from the family unit but also when the Ministry of Children and Families and parents are activity working on family reunification.

Practice:

Occasionally the ministry is asked by MCFD social workers to issue funds to allow a family unit to find suitable accommodation when there is a plan to imminently return the child/ren to their care.  The family unit may or may not have received the temporary shelter top up when the child/ren were removed from their care.
 
  • The ministry will issue Temporary Absence Assistance for up to three months prior to the return date to accommodate this request.

“with respect  to a parent, means a child, other than a child who is 18 years of age and is a person with disabilities, who resides in the parent’s place of residence for more than 50% of each month and relies on that parent for the necessities of life, and includes a child in circumstances prescribed under subsection (2);”

Background:

In 2003 the field was sent an e-mail from the Director of Social Policy Branch which stated:
 
Until further notice, please do not discontinue the MNS (including grand parented former Schedule C, section 2(1)(l) awards for any client who exits disability assistance because they turn 65 or because they become eligible for CPP Benefits.

This e-mail has been interpreted differently in different regions.  Some regions continue to issue the full amount of MNS  a client was receiving prior to exiting assistance, some regions issue on a declining basis as income increases and some regions have forgotten about this e-mail and the client does not continue to receive MNS after exiting assistance.  This direction to the field is easily lost because it is not supported in regulation, nor is it found in the OLR.

Purpose:

As Region 2 and 3 align efforts with the joint telephone strategy it is imperative that staff in these two regions have clarity and apply the original e-mail in a consistent manner.

Practice:

When a client exits disability assistance because of turning age 65 or becoming eligible for CPP, and is in receipt of the MNS, their monthly rate of MNS will decline as their other income increases.

For example:

 

Before age 65 the client’s disability assistance was $906.42 + $400.00 Schedule C Tribunal award for a total income of $1306.42.  With OAS/GIS and Senior’s Supplement the client will be eligible for $1218.77 which is less than the client was receiving while on assistance.  In this case the client would be eligible for a top up of $1306.42 - $1218.77 = $87.65.  This would be paid via code 29 (Grandparented Schedule C Tribunal Award)

 
Another example:
 
Client receives $906.42 disability assistance + $225.00 MNS for a total income of $1131.42.  Client is eligible for CPP of $1000.00 and should go off assistance as the CPP rate is higher than the disability assistance rate.  However $1000.00 in monthly income is less than the client was receiving while on disability assistance and MNS.  So the client is issued the difference between disability assistance and MNS ($1131.42) and CPP ($1000.00) for a total of $131.42.  This would be issued under the appropriate MNS codes:  22, 24 or 28.
 
Where the client exits assistance due to being in receipt of OAS/GIS, the file needs to be reviewed quarterly as this income rises quarterly.  Where the client exits disability assistance due to CPP benefits, the file will need to be reviewed annually.
 
Impacts:

 

This is not a practice change for Region 2.

In Region 3 there are some clients who continue to receive their full Schedule C tribunal award or MNS amount regardless of their income.  These clients will be grandfathered and will continue to receive these amounts.  From this date forward any clients exiting disability assistance due to age or receiving CPP benefits will have their income treated according to this practice advisory.
 

Note:

There is no eligibility for other supplements.

Purpose:

 

This practice advisory will clarify the process by which MHSD will receive and respond to requests from MCFD for electronic information about MHSD clients and dependents.

Practice:

 
MCFD will request, in writing, information on a file or a person.  MCFD will make requests specifying the appropriate legislation under which the request is made, for example, Section 96.  The request will be sent via fax, e-mail or in person to Regional office, using the attached template.
 
Child, Family and Community Service Act Section 96 Template 
 
In an emergency, MCFD requests may be made by telephone and followed up, as soon as possible, with a written request.
 
SD will respond to the request by its “requested by” date.  As appropriate, responses will be in either verbal and/or written form.
 
Note:  When responding to a MCFD emergency request, the SD verbal response should be put in writing as soon as possible, attached to the MCFD written request (when it is received) and returned to the requestor.
 
A comment will be entered on the electronic file history by the designate, noting:  “Responded to request from MCFD.  Details may be obtained at Regional Office 300.”  All MCFD requests, with copies of SD responses attached, will be batch-filed and retained at the Regional Office.
 
Requests from MCFD will be routed to mailbox:  HSD Office 300.  A regional designate will respond to the MCFD request.
 
 
If there is an ongoing Family Service file and the Social Worker has the client’s permission to talk to the EAW about issues, the EAW may do so.  The EAW must ensure that the Social Worker has the client’s permission.

Taxi Saver Program 
 
The Taxi Saver Program provides registered handyDART clients with greater convenience for spontaneous travel when handyDART cannot accommodate their travel needs.
 
How it Works
 
Taxi Saver provides a 50% subsidy towards the cost of taxi rides. Eligible individuals can purchase a $80 package of Taxi Saver coupons at a cost of $40. This package can be purchased once every month. The coupons come in denominations of $1, $2 and $5.
 
The handyDART client uses the coupons to pay the dollar meter rate of taxi fare. For example, if a taxi fare is $5.80, the passenger pays $5.00 in coupons and .80¢ in change. (Taxi drivers do not give change on Taxi Saver coupons.)
 
Eligibility
 
You need a handyPASS to buy and use Taxi Saver coupons. handyPASS eligibility is based on what type of disability you have, and how it prevents you from using conventional public transit.

Room and Board 

A family unit that is living in a room and board situation (other than in a special care facility or with a parent or child of a person in the family unit) is eligible to receive the smaller of the following amounts:
  • the sum of the actual cost of room and board plus the amounts shown in Rate Table: Payment of Assistance - Room and Board Situations [see Rate Tables] for each client and dependent child in the family unit
     
  • the amount calculated under Schedule A for the applicable family unit size  
Room and Board with Parent or Child  

A family unit living in a room and board situation with a parent or child of a person in the family unit is only eligible to receive the support allowance applicable to the family unit (that is, the family unit is not eligible for shelter allowance).

If two or more family units share the same place of residence, the actual shelter costs of any one of the units is the lesser of the following:
  • the calculation of the following steps:
     
    1. dividing the actual shelter costs for all of the family units by the number of persons occupying the residence
       
    2. multiplying the result by the number of persons in that one family unit
       
  • the amount declared by the family unit as its shelter cost

​Shared Parenting Assistance

Shared parenting assistance (SPA) is available to recipients of income assistance and disability assistance. Recipients of hardship assistance are not eligible for SPA.
 
To be eligible for SPA, the parents must provide a court order or shared parenting agreement filed in court showing that they have a child or children who are not listed as dependants under their file but who reside with them for no less than 40 per cent of each month (11 nights in the month of February, or 12 nights in the other calendar months).
 
In situations where parents have a fifty-fifty custody arrangement under a shared custody court order or a shared parenting agreement, and they cannot agree on designating which parent will claim the child as a dependant for assistance purposes, neither parent may claim the child or children as a dependent child or children, but both parents are eligible for SPA.
For clients who do not have a court order or shared parenting agreement filed in court, a family justice counsellor is able to assist with this process.

Who is financially Independent?

To be eligible for income assistance, at least one applicant in a family unit must demonstrate that he or she has been financially independent for at least two consecutive years prior to applying for assistance.The two-year period of financial independence must be consecutive, but does not have to be the two consecutive years immediately prior to applying for assistance. The two-year period does not have to be two calendar years; the two-year count can start when the applicant started working.Applicants are considered to have been financially independent if they meet at least one of the following criteria:

  • have worked for at least 840 hours in each of two consecutive years
  • have earned at least $7,000 in gross income in each of two consecutive years
  • have been employed for a portion of two consecutive years, and for the balance of the two years, either:
    • have served a waiting period for or received Employment Insurance (EI)
    • have received income from a private or public income replacement program (for example, Workers’ Compensation Board, Canada Pension Plan, Disability Insurance)

How do you verify financial independence?

    The following are examples of documents that may be used to verify financial independence:

    • Pay records or letter from employer(s) verifying employment income and period of employment
    • Records of Employment
    • T4 slips or Canada Revenue Agency, Notice of Assessment for the required time period
    • Canada Pension Plan (CPP) Statement of Contributions

    What happens if there is an absence of verification?

    In cases where all indications are that the applicant has been financially independent and meets the eligibility criteria, but has exhausted all avenues for direct or indirect verification (rent receipts, etc.), signed declarations from the applicant are acceptable. * SEE FORMS *

      Who is exempt?

      Persons with disabilities are exempt from the two-year financial independence requirement. In addition, if either an applicant or the spouse (if applicable) is in one of the following categories, the entire family unit is exempt from this requirement:

      • applicants under age 19
      • applicants who are pregnant, have dependent children, have a foster child, or have a child in the home of a relative (CIHR)
      • applicants who have or had a medical condition that either:
        • will prevent them from working for a total of at least 30 days from the date of application
        • prevented them from working for at least six months during the two years immediately prior to applying for assistance
      • applicants who were either:
        • supported by an employed spouse for at least two consecutive years
        • supported for part of the two years and, during the remainder of the two years, met the financial independence requirement (on a pro-rata basis) on their own
      • applicants who were incarcerated in a provincial or federal correctional institution for at least six months during the two years immediately prior to applying for assistance
      • regardless of the applicant’s current age, applicants who were in the care of the Ministry of Children and Family Development (MCFD), including those with youth agreements, when they turned 19 years of age (this includes persons in the care of the state in another province of Canada)
      • applicants who have, within the past six months, separated from an abusive spouse or fled an abusive relative with whom they resided, and as a result, their ability to work is impaired
      • applicants with a two-year diploma or certificate, bachelor’s degree, or higher from a post-secondary institution
      • applicants who have persistent multiple barriers to employment
      • applicants who reside with and care for a spouse who has a physical or mental condition that precludes them from leaving home for the purposes of employment
      • applicants who are providing full-time care for a non-dependent child under an agreement with MCFD

        In the care of, or had a youth agreement with, MCFD upon turning 19 years of age E-mail or letter from the social worker, or a telephone conversation with an official of the relevant organization, confirming eligibility

      When should discrestion be applied?supervisor may use discretion to authorize the issuance of assistance in cases where, due to circumstances beyond an applicant’s control:

      • the applicant has been prevented from searching for, accepting or continuing employment and could not have achieved two consecutive years of financial independence prior to applying for income assistance, and
      • the family unit would otherwise experience undue hardship if eligibility were denied.

      Factors beyond an applicant's control could include the following examples:

      • long term incapacitating physical, social or mental health problems, such that two consecutive years of financial independence would not have been possible
      • long term dependency upon government assistance, such that two consecutive years of financial independence would not have been possible
      • chronic medical problems or addictions, which prevent two consecutive years of financial independence.
      • extended periods of caring for dependent or disabled family members such that two consecutive years of financial independence would not have been possible
      • previously restricted to living in a community, or country, where the economic and/or social conditions prohibited or precluded the possibility of two consecutive years of financial independence

      AND

      • Possibility of undue hardship:
      • The family unit will be unable to secure basic food, shelter and/or required medical attention if denied income assistance. Reapplication
      • Applicants previously granted assistance as a result of discretion provided in policy must again meet the two-year financial independence requirement upon application.

​Time Limits

Under theEmployment and Assistance Actand Regulation, income assistance is limited to two out of five years (24 out of 60 months).
 
After the time limit is reached, the recipient may become ineligible or reductions may be applied. The Employment and Assistance Regulation exempts some recipients from time limits.
 

Time limits do not apply to persons receiving assistance under the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Act.

To be eligible for income assistance or disability assistance, applicants must meet Canadian citizenship requirements, make a claim for refugee protection with the Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), or possess a Temporary Resident Permit.
Applicants who are refugee claimants, Temporary Resident Permit holders, and persons under a removal order that cannot be executed must provide immigration document IMM 1442 that specifies they are in Canada under these categories when applying for regular assistance and disability assistance.
 
To prove their status in Canada, clients must provide one of the following:
  • Confirmation of Permanent Residence (IMM5292) or Permanent Resident Card or prior to June 28, 2002: Record of Landing (IMM1000) [see Forms and Letters]
  • Canadian Citizenship Card or document
  • Canadian passport
  • Temporary Resident Permit (IMM1442) (prior to June 28, 2002: Minister's Permit)
  • documentation of claim for refugee protection with the Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) (IMM1442) [see Identification Requirements-Proof of Identity]
  • documentation of claim with CIC’s Pre-Removal Risk Assessment
  • documentation from Federal Court of Canada to place the client’s removal order on hold until it decides whether to review the PRRA’s decision.
  • documentation of inexecutable removal order issued by CIC
  • documentation of protected person status (Convention refugee or person in need of protection)

The No-Charge Psychiatric Medication Plan (Plan G) is available to individuals of any age who are registered with a mental health services centre and who demonstrate clinical and financial need. The plan provides coverage of certain psychiatric medications.
 

Individual patient eligibility is determined by the patient's physician and the local mental health services centre. Registration is required.

 

The drugs eligible for coverage under the No-Charge Psychiatric Medication Plan are listed in the Plan G Formulary by both brand and generic name. Drugs in the formulary identified as "Limited Coverage" require prior Special Authority approval from PharmaCare. For these medications, a patient's physician must submit a Special Authority Request to PharmaCare.

 

For more information on the plan, contact your local mental health service centre, listed in the telephone directory's blue pages under "Health Authorities" or, in Vancouver and Richmond, contact Vancouver Coastal Health. All applicants and adult dependants are required to have a verified and valid Social Insurance Number (SIN).  Documents that may be used for verification of a SIN consist of:
  • A valid SIN card
  • A copy of a valid SIN card on the client’s existing file.
  • A receipt issued by Service Canada in place of a SIN card, until the card arrives, if the receipt verifies the applicant’s social insurance number.
  • An original Notice of Assessment from Canada Revenue Agency containing SIN and name, or a copy of this document on the client’s existing file.
  • Other original formal documentation from the Government of Canada that contains social insurance number and name, or a copy of this documentation on the client’s existing file.
Note: A valid SIN card refers to a Social Insurance Card issued by Service Canada.  Metal cards that have Government of Canada printed on them are not valid SIN cards.

​Purpose:

To outline the basic principles of offsite administration.

 

Practice:

 
Staff identifies clients who would be better served through a Third Party Administrator.  The  Supervisor may verbally notify or send the client a letter outlining concerns raised by their behaviour, expectations for the future, and possible consequences if concerns continue (Third Party Administration).  All decisions to have a client administered offsite must be reviewed and approved by a Supervisor.

  

Referrals to a Third Party Administrator
 
  1. When the Supervisor has reviewed and approved the decision to administer assistance a letter is sent to the lient to advise them of the decision.  The letter will note the client is not to contact or attend any ministry office after that date. (sample letter – attachment #1)
  2. Comments on history screen must clearly explain the reasons for referral.
  3. File to be b.f.’d for 6 month review.
  4. The Employment and Assistance Office will establish administrative protocols with the Third Party Administrator.  Protocols to be located in a place that is readily accessible to staff.  Protocols will include method of referral (format, information to be included in referral), method of contact and time frame for response.
  5. The ministry worker and Third Party Administrator will review administered clients every six months, or more often if individual circumstances warrant.  If it is determined that administration is no longer necessary, the Supervisor will advise the client by letter that their file is no longer to be administered and they may resume contact with the EAO.  A copy of the letter is sent to the contractor. (attachment #2)
 

Applicants who were previously administered due to Health and Safety concerns

  1. The worker and/or Supervisor will exercise discretion with regards to taking the application when a former administered client wishes to reapply for assistance.  If a former client approaches the office in person the file will be reviewed and client behaviour observed.  If it is determined that the application can be taken in the office it is suggested that the application be completed at a wicket.  If it is determined that the client must have the application taken at the administration site, the worker or Supervisor will contact the Third Party Administrator to arrange an appointment time for the EAW to complete the application with the client.  The 21 day work search period applies in these cases unless it has been determined that the client meets the immediate need criteria or requires an expedited application.
  2. If a former, administered client contacts the office by phone, the decision to have the application taken in the office, over the phone, or at the administration site will be determined by a review of the file.

Transfer of Administered Clients

  1. Supervisor to Supervisor file transfer.

Topic: Medical Transportion - Definition of local vs. non-local
Policy:
Purpose:
 
To define local versus non-local medical transportation in order to assist staff in determining eligibility for the medical transportation supplement.

 

Practice:

Medical transportation supplements are provided only to recipients of income assistance or disability assistance who are eligible for general health supplements or are facing a life threatening health need.

 
The supplement of up to 20 cents per kilometre may be provided for medical transportation within the local area when:
  • Essential medical treatment is required.
  • There are extraordinary transportation costs which are needs significantly in excess of those that can reasonably be incorporated into normal daily living (e.g. Daily medical tests or treatments over an extended period of time)
  • All alternative options have been explored, including family, and voluntary agencies.
  • The client provides proof of the expected medical transportation costs.
 
Supplementary assistance for non-local, non-emergency medical transportation is only considered when the required medical treatment is not available in the local community.
 
In region 3 there are four local areas. 
  • Vancouver to maple ridge and the township of langley, and all communities in between.
  • Abbotsford/mission
  • Chilliwack
  • Hope
 
Clients living beyond maple ridge and the township of langley requiring transportation to vancouver or surrey would be considered for non-local medical transportation if the required medical service is not available in the local community.
 
Clients living in langley, maple ridge, chilliwack or hope requiring transportation to abbotsford would be considered for non-local medical transportation if the required medical service is not available in the local community.
 
Local medical transportation is to be paid via code 10.
Non-local medical transportation is to be paid via code 62.
Transportation in excess of 20 cents per kilometre is paid via code 18 with ppim approval.

Below is a brief explanation of resources that may be available to you.  Please keep this information sheet for future reference.
 

Please click here for the PWD Information Sheet 

EMPLOYMENT PROGRAMS
The Ministry supports Person’s with Disabilities with obtaining employment. The Ministry has funded specific programs to assist Person’s with Disability with accessing employment. These programs also provide disability supports and assisted technology. Please contact a worker at 604-927-2949 to inquire about programs in your area.
 
EARNINGS EXEMPTION
Persons with Disabilities are eligible for a $800 employment earnings exemption for a single person & $1600 for a family unit where both adults have PWD.  If you are working you must declare the income along with any other income on your stub by the 5th of each month. Proof of any income you declare must also be submitted i.e. (pay stubs, income tax refunds etc.)  PWD clients with earnings exceeding Ministry rates are eligible for continued Medical Services only. A worker will contact you to discuss this should your income exceed our rates.
 
MEDICAL SERVICES ONLY
Clients who start receiving Federal Income supports such as Canada Pension or Old Aged Security are eligible to retain Medical coverage. This includes MSP premiums, dental, optical, prescriptions, medical equipment etc. If you require medical equipment you must contact a worker.
 
PRESCRIPTIONS
Pharmacare covers everyone receiving Disability Assistance.  Prescriptions can be obtained at no charge by presenting your CareCard to the pharmacist.  If Pharmacare does not cover a prescription your Disability Assistance will not pay for it.. Your physician may be able to prescribe an alternate medication or apply for an exception by contacting Pharmacare directly.  There is no need to contact a worker.
 
OPTICAL SERVICES
The Ministry covers routine eye examinations once every two years. Glasses are provided once every 3 years.  New lenses may be provided when an optometrist confirms a significant change in prescription.  To obtain this benefit, present your CareCard to your optical supplier.  There is no need to contact a worker.
 
DENTAL SERVICES (Including Dentures)
Please contact your dentist or denturist directly, have your health care card available, advise them you have PWD Ministry sponsored medical coverage.  If further dental work is needed, your dentist may submit an Application to Exceed Annual Limit directly to Health Services.  The dentist has these forms in his office. There is no need to contact a worker.  If you pay for any dental services you will not be reimbursed.
 
ANNUAL BUS PASS
You are eligible to purchase an annual bus pass. Prices may change but currently they are $45.00 per year.  You must pay for this with your support money; you will not receive extra funds.  To apply for the bus pass call 1-866-866-0800 press 4 and then press 3.  There is no need to contact a worker.
 
MEDICAL TRANSPORTATION
Emergency ambulance service is covered by MSP.  Disability Assistance does not provide extra funding to attend routine doctor appointments.  If you are unable to take a bus for medical reasons and you have an extraordinary number of medical appointments, you may be eligible for medical transportation benefits.  Your doctor will have to complete a form, which is available at our office.
 
 
MEDICAL EQUIPMENT
For equipment under $500, submit a written prescription and diagnosis from your doctor or occupational therapist, and a price quote from a supplier.  If approved, a worker will issue a form that you take to the store with you.  If you are unable to come to the office, advise the worker and the forms can be faxed to the store (make sure you give the worker the fax number). For equipment over $500 the request is sent to Health Assistance Branch for review. You will be notified in writing if your request is approved.  If you pay for medical equipment yourself you will not be reimbursed.
 
MEDICAL EQUIPMENT REPAIRS
For equipment repairs under $500 please have that supplier fax the request to repair the item to your worker for pre-appoval. If approved a worker will issue a form to the supplier for the repair. For repairs over $500 they are sent to Victoria Health Assistance Branch for review and approval. If you pay for repairs yourself you will not be reimbursed.
 
ORTHOTICS AND BRACING DEVICES
If you need a custom fitted product, go to a Certified Orthotic Supplier and present your CareCard.  It is not necessary to contact a worker.  You can find Orthotic Suppliers in the yellow pages.
If you are purchasing an over the counter product you will not be reimbursed.
 
PHYSIOTHERAPY, MASSAGE THERAPY, PODIATRY SERVICES AND CHIROPRACTIC SERVICES
Medical Services Plan (MSP) covers physiotherapy, massage therapy, chiropractic and non-surgical podiatry treatments, to a combined limit of up to 10 visits per calendar year for recipients who have Ministry of Employment & Income Assistance general health supplements coverage. If you require additional visit clients must provide a written request from a physician or therapist including the following:
-          the name and address of therapist and doctor;
- diagnosis of the condition (specifically whether the condition is acute or chronic);
- the type, frequency and number of visits required; and
- the medical reason(s) further treatment is required.
-          Forward your request to the office. A worker will send your request to Health Assistance Branch for review. You will be notified in writing if your request is approved.
 
MEDICAL SUPPLIES
Prescribed medical supplies will be provided if they are considered essential to your health.  All requests must be made in writing by a physician.  Submit a doctor note stating the diagnosis, supplies needed, how many are needed each week, and how long you will need them for.  Also submit a price quote from a supplier.  If the cost is between $200.00 - 500.00 then two price quotes are needed.  If the cost is over $500.00 or the supply will be needed for more that 90 days we will try to arrange for a contracted supplier to set up a standing order.
 
NUTRITIONAL PRODUCTS
Submit a written prescription & diagnosis from your doctor, including the expected duration of need, type of product required & amount required per day.  If the product is needed for more than 3 months, you must submit a nutritional assessment by a dietician or nutritionist.
 
 
Monthly Nutrional Supplement
PWD clients with severe medical conditions causing a chronic, progressive deterioration of health with symptoms of wasting may wish to apply for this supplement. The Monthly Nutritional Supplement (MNS) is only available to persons with disabilities in receipt of disability assistance (support & shelter) who meet the specific medical criteria. You must contact a worker to request the required forms. Your doctor must complete the forms and the original completed form must be returned to the office. The form is then sent to Victoria Health Services for review. You will receive a letter in writing advising you if you are approved.
 
DIET SUPPLEMENT
Under the BC Employment and Assistance Program, diet assistance can be provided to persons facing the expense of a special diet as a result of a specific medical condition.  To apply for or continue receiving diet assistance, please be aware of the following criteria.
 
Diet assistance is as follows:
  • $10 per month for a person who requires a restricted sodium diet as a result of a specific medical condition;
  • $35 per month for a person who has diabetes;
  • $30 per month for a person who requires kidney dialysis if the person is not eligible under the service provided by the Ministry of Health Services;
  • $40 per month for a person who requires a high protein diet and has any of the following:
    • Cancer requiring nutritional support during radiation, chemotherapy, surgical cancer therapy and ongoing treatment.
    • Chronic inflammatory bowel disease, Crohn’s and ulcerative colitis
    • HIV/AIDS, chronic bacterial infection and tuberculosis
    • Hyperthyroidism, osteoporosis
    • Hepatitis B or C
  • $40 per month for a person who requires a gluten-free diet as a result of a specific medical condition;
  • $40 per month for a person who has dysphagia as a result of a specific medical condition;
  • $50 per month for a person who has cystic fibrosis.
To apply for diet assistance, please obtain confirmation from your doctor or a registered dietician/nutritionist that outlines:
 
  • our specific medical condition;
  • what type of diet you need;
  • how it relates to your medical condition; and,
  • how long it is needed.
Please bring this information to your local office for staff to determine whether you are eligible.

The reconsideration is conducted based on the legislation and regulations.  A reconsideration decision is made and mailed within either:
  • 10 business days after receiving the completed SD0100, or
  • where a person consents to an extension granted by the ministry, within 20 business days after receiving the completed SD0100.

A person’s request for an extension may be made either orally or in writing, and should generally be accommodated by the ministry by granting the person’s request.

Remember: The person must have delivered the SD0100 within 20 business days of being notified of the decision being reconsidered.
 
Extensions must be recorded by updating the file in RAS by selecting the Extension Granted box.  When this box is selected, a new due date will automatically be generated.  Record the details of the extension in the person’s file.  In particular record, who made the request for an extension (advocate, client, family member) and when, who consented to the request and when, and how the request was made (orally or in writing).
 
Inform the person of the new due date when the reconsideration decision will be made and mailed.  Also remind the person that the ministry cannot accept new information to be considered at reconsideration after the reconsideration decision has been made.  Encourage the person to obtain and submit new information as quickly as possible before the new due date.
 
There are two general situations in which an extension may be granted:
 
When the Person Requests Additional Time
 
After delivering the SD0100, a person or the person’s advocate may request an extension of 10 additional business days if more time is needed to obtain and submit information before the reconsideration decision is made.

When the Ministry Wishes to Seek Clarification

When the ministry wishes to seek clarification about information submitted at reconsideration by a person or on a person’s behalf, an extension of 10 additional business days may be granted when the person provides consent.
 
The Reconsideration Officer should seek consent of the person requesting the reconsideration if clarification is required in order to make a fair and fully informed reconsideration decision.

The person or the person’s advocate must provide their consent, either orally or in writing, before an extension is available to the ministry.  Without consent the ministry will be required to make and mail the reconsideration decision within 10 business days after receiving the completed SD0100.

To apply for a diet supplement, recipients must provide documentation from their medical practitioner, nurse practitioner or a registered dietitian that confirms the need for the diet supplement.  When a recipient requests a diet supplement, the following steps must be completed:
  1. Review medical documentation presented and already on the system.

    Prior to requesting new documentation, review to see if the ministry already has sufficient medical information to confirm eligibility for a diet supplement. If so, the need for new medical documentation may be waived.
  2. For cases that require new medical information, request documentation from the recipient using the Information Required – Medical template letter (HR3237) [see Forms and Letters].  Enclose a copy of the Diet Supplement Fact Sheet.
  3. Upon receipt of the required medical documentation, determine if the recipient is eligible for a diet supplement.  Run the Assisted Eligibility tool.
  4. If the recipient is found eligible for a diet supplement, enter the appropriate diet rate.  [For maximum rates, see Rate Table: Health Supplements and Programs - Diet Supplements.]
  5. Set a notification for review:

    • no more than 12 months for acute (short-term) conditions;
    • no more than 24 months for chronic (long-term) conditions.

      [For guidelines on assigning review dates, see Resources for Staff – Guidelines for Reviewing Diet Supplements.]
  6. Advise recipient of decision and document decision.
  7. If a recipient is eligible for a high protein or dysphasia diet they may also be eligible for assistance towards a blender.  [For maximum rates, see Rate Table: Health Supplements and Programs - Diet Supplements.]  It should be noted that a blender was issued.
  8. If the recipient is found ineligible for a diet supplement, a Diet Supplement Denial letter (HR3139) [see Forms and Letters] must be sent to the recipient advising them of the decision, along with a copy of the Reconsideration and Appeals Brochure [Resources for Clients]

FASB will notify us once the EFT has been successfully recalled/cancelled.  If a client is still eligible for a portion of their cheque, the Ministry can re-issue a new Imprest Cheque for the correct amount once we have received confirmation that the original cheque has been recalled/cancelled.

 *** There is a delay of when FASB requests a recall to the time they actually receive confirmation from Treasury that the funds have been recovered.  It usually takes a day or two to receive back EFT recalls and MIS will not be updated until FASB can confirm the funds have been returned.***

Topic: Guidelines for Issuing Comforts Allowances for Children Residing with Parents in MOH Licensed and MOH Registered Supportive Recovery Homes (SRH)
Policy:
The Ministry is committed to protecting those recovering from substance abuse challenges through the use of MOH licensed substance abuse residential facilities or MOH registered Supportive Recovery Houses. Currently, while living in an MOH registered or licensed facility, the client receives a comforts allowance and the facility receives a per diem payment. The Ministry now has the ability to also pay a per diem and comforts allowance for children to stay with their parent:

  • in an MOH licensed substance abuse residential facility, as long as the licence specifies children are permitted.
  • in a MOH registered supportive recovery home, as long as the facility is validated by both MCFD and the Ministry of Health as a place which is appropriate for children.
Important Information
  • In order to apply the policy direction a manual case management procedure must be used.
  • The system cannot generate multiple Comforts Supplements when the Case is coded as 05 Long Term Care (LTC), so the file must remain as 01 or 03 (PWD or ETW/PPMB).
  • This is a similar process currently practiced when temporary shelter top-up is provided.
  • The amount of Comforts Supplement the family unit would be eligible to receive must be calculated manually and provided under Support Supplement code (41 or 71).
  • If the family unit is not receiving Family Bonus, follow the procedure for adding the Family Bonus top-up supplement in addition to the Comforts Supplement.
  • All processes require manual calculations, manual administration and monitoring.
  • The Per Diem billing forms must also be monitored to ensure each dependant is added and FASB notified.
 
Examples
 
Support

 

Example is based on a single parent with dependants with a Support rate of $375.58. 
 
Parent with 2 Children
  • $95 x 3 = $285.
  • Subtract comforts from the support to determine the amount to be placed in Manual Administered Amounts.
  • $90.58 is placed in Manual Administered to stop the full support amount going to client within the Monthly Benefit Plan.
  • Make notes on the case to indicate why the file has been set up this way
 
Parent with 5 children
  • $95 x 5 = $475
  • Full support of $375.58 is issued within the Monthly Benefit Plan.
  • Wait until after Cheque Cut Off to issue the additional amount using a One Time Allowance benefit Plan using the Support code.
  • Create a User Defined Activity Notification created on the Monday after Cut-Off to issue the additional funds needed to equal the total Comforts amount.
  • Subtract: $475-375.58+$99.42 and issue this amount using the Support Codes on a One Time Allowance Benefit Plan.
  • Make notes on the case to indicate why the file has been set up this way    
Shelter
  • If Shelter is not being maintained, end date rent amount from Expense tab.
  • If rent is being maintained, update the amount to reflect shelter rate.
  • If the rent is over the rate,  money from the “Comforts” (Support) portion can  be applied to pay rent.
  • If rate is less than rent and paid directly to the landlord no deduction will occur from Comforts.
  • Review whether manual administration is required.
Family Bonus

  • Review the amount of Family Bonus the family is currently receiving to determine if any top-up is required.

Repayments

  • Recapture repayment amounts.

Topic: Registered Disability Savings Plan - Effective January 30, 2013
Policy:
Registered Disability Savings Plan - Effective January 30, 2013

The ministry has been working with disability stakeholders to increase the use of RDSPs. The RDSP is an important financial tool for clients with disabilities and their families to save for the future, increase their standard of living and meet disability-related costs.
 
Previously, funds held inside an RDSP were considered an exempt asset.  Funds withdrawn from an RDSP were exempt, as income, in the month they were withdrawn, but were considered an asset thereafter.  As a withdrawn asset, they were subject to asset limits in the regulations.
 
As a result, income and disability assistance clients would have been found ineligible for being over the asset limit if they held funds withdrawn from an RDSP. 
 
Example: A client may wish to hold funds in a bank account for several months while they shop for a vehicle or other item. 
 
A regulatory amendment has been approved which exempts disbursements from an RDSP as an asset.
 
Moving forward, clients should be advised to report all disbursements and  clearly document the funds originated from a RDSP. ​

New Process for Family Maintenance (FM) Forms

Certain forms are treated as legal documents for the Family Maintenance Program (see list below) and are being date stamped, scanned and/or batch-filed.

These forms are used in legal proceedings by the courts and must not be marked in any way.

DO NOT SCAN; Batch-FILE, OR SHRED these FM FORMS. Do not create notifications. Do not write on, mark or change the document in any way. You do not have to send notification to the FMW. NOTE: If you must date-stamp the document use a post-it note.

The original FORM must be forwarded immediately to the FMW via house mail. Once received in House-Mail the receiving office must not date stamp these forms either. They must give the original document to the FMW without marking it in any way. Use a post-it for any necessary notations.

The FMW will scan/profile the document when it is received. Some FM documents must be used for a court file and only the original with the original signatures is acceptable to the court. If these documents have been marked or changed they are unacceptable to the court and a new one is required.This results in even more time wasted and unnecessary extra work. The document management Matrix will be updated with the correct procedures. It will also indicate which of the original documents need to be retained for the client’s Case File.
